newsitem.title: USA: US WCoast prods decline on refinery returns, APIs.
newsitem.headline: US WCoast prods decline on refinery returns, APIs.

text.p: U.S. West Coast product prices declined on late Tuesday, with traders convinced refineries were doing better after last week's blackout.
"I think there's plenty of gasoline around and with the majors out of the market it'll soften a bit," a trader said.
The American Petroleum Institute (API) reported a drop in refinery use last week, despite company denials of problems. Utilisation dropped a hefty 7.8 percent to 81.3 percent.
But prices sagged today with fewer refiners needing to buy and cargoes expected by week's end.
Conventional-grade gasoline in Los Angeles fell one cent from midday to 64/65 cents a gallon, with premium quality seven cents higher.
CARB-grade gasoline was notionally a half cent higher at 68.50/69.50 cents a gallon.
API data showed gasoline held in secondary storage out west fell 1.21 million barrels to 28.8 million, but traders noted it remained 764,000 barrels above year-ago.
Low sulphur diesel in L.A. slipped a half cent to 68.50/69.50 cents, in line with trader predictions that the market was overvalued after refinery unit problems.
With problems resolved, EPA was seen falling to its usual five-cent discount to CARB, traders said.
The API also reported a 643,000 barrel rise in West Coast distillate stocks.
Jet fuel sagged, falling between two and 2.50 cents to 69.50/70 cents on forecasts of foreign cargoes and inventory data.
And business shifted from August to September after two quiet sessions when traders attended a golf tournament.
August gasolines were seen 1.50 below September.
